publication.title: Who Should Access Electronic Patient Records
publication.authors: ana ferreira,catarina pinho,sá catarina,edite mendes,emanuel santos,fátima silva,filipa sousa,filipe gomes,fernando abreu,fernando mota,francisca aguiar,francisco faria,francisco macedo,simão martins,ricardo joão cruz correia
publication.jconf: International Joint Conference on Biomedical Engineering Systems and Technologies
publication.keyword: Electronic Patient Record;Medical Records;Random Sampling;Access Control;
publication.abstract: Access control to Electronic Patient Records (EPR) may greatly depend on users' objectives and needs. The purpose of this study is to assess the opinions of medical doctors within a university hospital towards access control to an EPR. We selected a randomized sample of 58 doctors from a university hospital and 45 structured interviews were applied. 42 respondents (93%) agree

publication.title: Clustering Fetal Heart Rate Tracings by Compression
publication.authors: c. costa santos,j. bernardes,paul m. b. vitányi
publication.keyword: Algorithmic Information Theory;Background Knowledge;Domain Specificity;Individual Object;Information Content;Requirement Specification;Fetal Heart Rate;
publication.abstract: Fetal heart rate (FHR) monitoring, before and during labor, is a very important medical practice in the detection of fetuses in danger. We clustered FHR tracings by compression in order to identify abnormal ones. We use a recently introduced approach based on algorithmic information theory, a theoretical, rigorous and well-studied notion of information content in individual objects. The new method

publication.title: Computational Depth
publication.abstract: We introduce Computational Depth, a measure for the amount of "nonrandom" or "useful" information in a string by considering the difference of various Kolmogorov complexity measures. We investigate three instantiationsof Computational Depth: Basic Computational Depth, a clean notion capturing the spirit of Bennett's Logical Depth. Time- Computational Depth and the resulting concept of Shallow Sets, a generalization of sparse and

publication.title: Low-Depth Witnesses are Easy to Find
publication.keyword: Computational and Structural Complexity;kolmogorov complexity;Polynomial Time;Satisfiability;
publication.abstract: Abstract Antunes, Fortnow, van Melkebeek and Vinodchandran captured the notion of non-random information by computational depth, the difference between the polynomial-time-bounded Kol- mogorov,complexity,and,traditional Kolmogorov,complexity,We show,how,to find satisfying assignments,for formulas that have at least one assignment,of logarithmic,depth. The converse holds under,a standard,hardness,assumptions,though,fails if BPP = UP = EXP. We also show that under standard,hardness,assumptions,one cannot increase the depth of a string

publication.title: Using Depth to Capture Average-Case Complexity
publication.abstract: Abstract: We give therst characterization of Turing machines thatrun in polynomial-time on average. We show that a Turing machine Mruns in average polynomial-time if for all inputs x the Turing machineuses time exponential in the computational depth of x, where the computationaldepth is a measure of the amount of \useful&quot; information inx.

publication.title: Sophistication Revisited
publication.abstract: Abstract Kolmogorov complexity measures the ammount,of information in a string as the size of the shortest program,that computes the string. The Kolmogorov structure function divides the smallest program producing a string in two parts: the useful information present in the string, called sophistication if based on total functions, and the remaining accidental information. We formalize a connection between sophistication (due

publication.title: Depth as Randomness Deficiency
publication.authors: armando matos,andre souto,paul m. b. vitányi
publication.abstract: Depth of an object concerns a tradeoff between computation time and excess of pro- gram length over the shortest program length required to obtain the object. It gives an unconditional lower bound on the computation time from a given program in absence of auxiliary information. Variants known as logical depth and computational depth are expressed in Kolmogorov complexity theory. We

We also prove that for a particular type of distributions Shannon Entropy is able to capture the notion of computationally accessible information by relating it to time-bounded algorithmic entropy. publication.title: Time-Bounded Universal Distributions
publication.abstract: We show that under a reasonable hardness assumptions, the time-bounded Kolmogorov distribution is a universal samplable distribution. Under the same assumption we exactly characterize the worst-case running time of languages that are in average polynomial-time over all P-samplable distributions.

publication.title: Computational depth: Concept and applications
publication.authors: lance fortnow,dieter van melkebeek,n. v. vinodchandran
publication.abstract: We introduce Computational Depth, a measure for the amount of "nonrandom" or "useful" information in a string by considering the dierence of various Kolmogorov complexity measures. We investigate three instantiations of Computational Depth: - Basic Computational Depth, a clean notion capturing the spirit of Bennett's Logical Depth. We show that a Turing machine M runs in time polynomial on average
